instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H_REG: What is PP3V42_G3H_REG? PP3V42_G3H_REG is another way to say PP3V42_G3H. PP3V42_G3H_REG and PP3V42_G3H are a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message:
Working on a stack of <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>'s tonight and I have stumbled across a weird one. I had to replace the ISL as it had blown <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> MOSFETs. It came in with no power but occasionally gets a green light. When the light is on or off the PP3V42 is high (3.415 V), <SIGNAL>SMC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is 3.25V, I am investigating around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and noticed that <SIGNAL>P3V42G3H_BOOST</SIGNAL> seems high to me as on one side of <CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> I have 6.8V and the other side close to the coil as 3.3V. What else should I check for?
P.S. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1.2V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> high?
Voltage of <SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL>?
Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in Ohms?
F7040/41 fuses not blown?

<SIGNAL>P3V42G3H_BOOST</SIGNAL> being 'too high' is probably just your multimeter getting confused by the switching, if PP3V42 itself is alright then no worries about it.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P3V42G3H_BOOST</SIGNAL> MUST be higher.
It is usually aprox 5V higher than the output; check how a buck controller works...
However, it is not a DC voltage only there; as it uses the coil pulses.

=<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_REG</SIGNAL> is completely independent of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, on AC mode.

Check for corrosion around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
Don't forget <RESISTOR>R6991</RESISTOR>/92/95/96.

Assure =<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_CONN</SIGNAL> is stable; if not, means charger detects some leakage on the input of the board..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is high, 3.38v.
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDD</SIGNAL> is 5.469
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL> is 5.474
Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is -1.025 fluctuating Mega Ohms. May not be doing this right. Not sure why it would show negative unless I had the probes backwards.
The fuses F7040/41 appear fine.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: You are seeing a negative value because either you have power applied or there is residual charge on the rail. Is PPBUS even present and is it 12.56V? Check resistance between pin 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? DCIN present on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> isn't at 12.6v, only 1.3v. Charger was unplugged.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message:
Pins 17/18: 3 Ohms
Pins 27/28: 20 Ohms

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: Oh and yes, 16.8v on <SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: If there is no short on PPBUS then I would say you killed the 6259 or bad soldering. Also I asked DCIN on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, not the DCIN charger rail.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: I'm very sorry, I don't mean to be stupid but from the schematic it sounds like the <SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is the DCIN for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, but if not I'd definitely like to be corrected. I've replaced the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> twice, I'm concerned I may have a bad batch, Thanks a bunch for the help.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> yeah sorry that is correct. Does this board power on from a charged battery?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: No trouble, can't thank you guys enough. I'm out of the office at the moment but will be in around 5:00 PM EST. I'll give that a look and let you know.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: Sorry for the delay, under the weather. The board doesn't power on with the battery plugged in, but with just the power from the battery, I do get 11.8v on pin 24 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. On just the DC jack, I get 2v.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: Then the issue is not with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> as the system would power on without it. Still want to know resistance to GND on PPBUS.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: Resistance to GND from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.439v.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: My apologies, 2.08 Mega Ohms.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: Apologies, 1.81 Mega Ohms.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: If you gave a green light does the battery indicator work? I'm suspecting an SMC problem.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: Found a bad diode, very hard to see that it was cracked--<DIODE>D6990</DIODE>. Replaced the diode and now getting a green intermittent light on the charger. Checked <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, I now have a steady 12.28v. With the battery and charger plugged in, I get a steady green light, not orange. Jumped the power on pads to be sure the system won't turn on, no fan spin.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: PPBUS voltage without battery? If 12.23 and the battery indicator also not working I will still say bad SMC.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Intermittent Green Light No Power
threads.message: Thanks a ton, definitely a dead SMC, I <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high at 3.3v. Damn, I really hate these. Can't thank you guys enough; really helped me out.
